Write to Between Main and Wall, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or E-mail mainwall@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

headline: ATLAS COPCO BUYING U.S. ELECTRIC-TOOL MAKER
abstract: The Swedish engineering company Atlas Copco A.B. agreed yesterday to buy the Milwaukee Electric Tool Corporation for about $550 million in cash. Milwaukee Electric Tool, which makes heavy-duty portable electric tools and accessories, had $367 million in sales last year. The company is owned by Esstar Inc. of Norwich, Conn., which is controlled by affiliates of the investment group Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. Atlas Copco, of Stockholm, said the deal would help build its share of the $2 billion United States electric-tool market. Atlas, which makes power tools, compressors and construction and mining equipment and had overall sales of $2.8 billion in 1994, said the acquisition would more than double its electric-tool sales worldwide.

headline: In India, U.S. Diplomacy Is Sounding a Lot Like Economics
abstract: Just hours before Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his entourage landed amid the chaos and crushing poverty of this historic trading center, the power grid for much of the area failed, plunging the homes that have electric power into darkness.   Such failures are fairly common here. But for Mr. Rubin, the fourth American Cabinet member to visit India since the start of the year, the timing was exquisite. Each official came to persuade India's leaders that it was not in their interest to allow a slowing in the broad movement to open their economy.

headline: Market Place; For CCH, a business law and tax publisher, times could be better, even in April.
abstract: AS Americans hustle to beat today's income-tax filing deadline, this should be the best of times for CCH Inc., the venerable business law and tax publishing corporation. But the company, known until Jan. 1 as Commerce Clearing House, is still engaged in an expensive restructuring program and absorbing heavy costs from the development of new products.   Securities analysts who follow CCH, of Riverwoods, Ill., generally rate the stock as a hold. They are likely to maintain that neutral rating, moreover, for some time.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Climb on Signs Of Lower North Sea Production
abstract: Crude oil prices climbed yesterday, stopping short of $20 a barrel, as traders grew concern that lower production in the North Sea would reduce supplies in the United States.   On other commodity markets, wheat rose, helping to lift the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities 0.74 point, to 237.28. Lumber prices fell.

headline: Acquisition of Technicolor Under Court Scrutiny Again
abstract: The deal that formed the foundation of Ronald O. Perelman's fortune, his 1982 acquisition of Technicolor, was under scrutiny today for the third time before the Delaware Supreme Court, in a case that could revise the ground rules for corporate takeovers.    The occasion was oral arguments in the case of Cinerama v. Technicolor, in which lawyers for Cinerama are charging that the directors of Technicolor Inc. were grossly negligent in agreeing to Mr. Perelman's $125 million acquisition of Technicolor. Cinerama, a shareholder of Technicolor at the time, is seeking a $40 million slice of the estimated $750 million profit made by Mr. Perelman when he sold the company in 1988, plus interest.

headline: Arbitration: Getting Down to Brass Knuckles
abstract: THE BEEF Gordon and Marion Newell of Safety Harbor, Fla., say their broker pitched them limited partnerships as secure, conservative investments. Monthly statements supported that claim, for years listing inflated prices even as the value of the securities was plunging. The Newells didn't know they were in deep water until they tried to sell and got half the price shown on the statement.   THE BROKER Merrill Lynch says the Newells understood the risks they were taking, turned down a settlement offer and are seeking an unreasonable eight times their losses. The broker, Arnold Plonski, opened the account with the Newells in 1982, less than a year after he ended a career as a real estate broker.

headline: Birth Control in China: Coercion and Evasion
abstract: From the highway, it takes 40 minutes to walk down a dirt road and then a long red-clay rut to where the "wild people" of these hills in southern Hunan Province have been living in isolation for nearly 30 years.   Ever since the Government smashed their houses in 1966 and cut them off from social services because they refused to abandon their ancestral lands, now partly inundated by a reservoir, 10 families -- scarcely 60 people -- have fended for themselves on this scruffy hillside, 15 miles southwest of Chenzhou, a city that itself was long regarded as the end of the line in this part of China.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Monday The Commerce Department releases housing completions for April. In March, completions increased 9.8 percent, but declined 9.1 percent in February.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;MCA's Value Growing, Seagram Chief Tells Shareholders
abstract: The president of Seagram, Edgar M. Bronfman Jr., told investors yesterday that MCA Inc. had become more valuable since Seagram first offered to gain control of it, but he did not provide details of his plans for the entertainment company.         Seagram, which officially takes over MCA next week, also reported a sharp gain in earnings resulting from the sale of its stake in Du Pont.

headline: EARNING IT;For Speakers And Schools, The Dickering
abstract: HIGHER education is a business, and business is fueled by quid pro quos. These truths are as valid for commencement speeches as for any other school activity.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TOM BROWN OFFERS $200 MILLION FOR PRESIDIO OIL
abstract: Tom Brown Inc. offered to buy the Presidio Oil Company yesterday for $200 million. Tom Brown, a petroleum producer based in Midland, Tex., did not offer details of its offer, which was made in a letter to the chairman of Presidio, George P. Giard Jr. Tom Brown, which said the deal would relieve Presidio of its heavy debt load, said a combination of the companies would be better than a debt restructuring. Robert L. Smith, president of Presidio, said the company had no immediate comment. Presidio missed a $3.3 million interest payment on its 13.25  percent senior gas-indexed notes on May 15. The company has 30 days to make the  payment before it defaults.

headline: INVESTING IT;Once-Humbled Thrifts Are Outrunning the Pack
abstract: TECHNOLOGY is hot, but savings and loans are hotter.         S.& L.'s? The same institutions whose recklessness personified the excesses of the 1980's? Whose penchant for risky loans nearly caused a financial meltdown? And whose bailout, at last tally, cost American taxpayers more than $200 billion?

headline: Austria Agrees To Compensate Nazis' Victims
abstract: The Parliament voted today to to pay compensation to an estimated 30,000 victims persecuted during Nazi rule, seeking to resolve an issue that has divided the nation since the end of World War II.         Lawmakers across the political spectrum, including the far-right party, supported a Government bill to establish a $50 million fund to compensate those  who were sent to concentration camps because they were Jews, Communists or homosexuals, and for those who fled into exile.

headline: Court Backs Grand Union Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: The Grand Union Company's Chapter 11 reorganization plan was confirmed today  by a United States Bankruptcy Court judge.         Under the plan, 10 million shares of new stock will be issued to holders of Grand Union's senior subordinated notes.

headline: International Briefs;ABN Amro Raises Its Offer for Orco
abstract: ABN Amro Bank N.V. said yesterday that it would offer 84.47 guilders a share, or a total of 460 million guilders ($291 million), for Orco Bank N.V., a bank based in Curacao, part of the Netherlands Antilles.          ABN Amro first expressed interest in Orco in February and said it expected to pay about 73.80 guilders a share. That initial offer caused protests by VEB,  a shareholders organization, and by Jaap Kroonenberg, a real estate broker who owns a 33 percent stake in Orco. They said the price was less than Orco was worth. ABN Amro said it had raised its bid because Orco's interest income and proceeds from its bond portfolio had risen. ABN Amro was asked to bid for Orco by the central bank of the Netherlands Antilles and by Orco itself.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UPJOHN BUYS A WARNER-LAMBERT VETERINARY BUSINESS
abstract: The Upjohn Company said yesterday that it had bought the Warner-Lambert Company's Parke-Davis veterinary business for an undisclosed sum. The business includes about 50 products sold in Germany, Britain, Ireland, Austria and Switzerland. Under the agreement, Warner-Lambert will continue to make the products, which Upjohn will sell. The purchase would bolster Upjohn's worldwide  veterinary business, which in 1994 had sales of about $350 million, by broadening the range of products sold in Europe. About 10 percent of Upjohn's overall revenue comes from animal-health products. The division makes and sells  a range of pharmaceutical products for livestock and pets.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMSAT OUTLINES ICE HOCKEY FRANCHISE FINANCING
abstract: The Comsat Corporation may finance its acquisition of the Quebec Nordiques ice hockey franchise through the sale of $200 million of preferred securities. The communications and entertainment company, based in Bethesda, Md., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to sell the securities through  a pair of special finance subsidiaries. Comsat said in the S.E.C. filing that it would use some of the proceeds to reduce about $115 million of commercial paper, and the remaining funds might be used to meet general corporate requirements and pay down debt incurred to purchase the Nordiques. Comsat already owns the Denver Nuggets NBA basketball franchise.

headline: Chase Is Turning to a Specialist To Help Sharpen Its Budget Ax
abstract: The banking industry's toughest cost-cutter is coming to the Chase Manhattan Corporation. That means the sun may soon set on the potted palms at Chase Manhattan Plaza near Wall Street -- and on the careers of thousands of the bankers whose offices they adorn.   Yesterday, Chase said it had hired Tandon Capital Associates, which has helped half a dozen banks cut spending and eliminate 15 to 25 percent of their jobs. Chase said it hoped to exceed its previously announced goal of reducing annual expenses by $400 million a year, 9 percent of its total.    Tandon Capital, a seven-member firm headed by Chandrika K. Tandon, a former consultant at McKinsey & Company, specializes in getting bank employees to recommend ways that their jobs can be streamlined and frills can be cut. These ideas have ranged from reducing the paperwork needed to open accounts to eliminating company-provided plants and the jobs of the people who water them.    Most of the costs eliminated, however, tend to be salaries. Last year, for example, the Tandon firm helped the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., develop a plan to eliminate 25 percent of its 20,000 jobs.    And yesterday, the Republic New York Corporation, the parent of Republic National Bank and Republic Bank for Savings, said that over the last four months, Tandon ran a cost-cutting campaign that would lead it to lay off 850 people, representing 15 percent of its work force.   Chase, a sprawling international banking company with 35,000 employees, is far more complex than the regional banking companies that Tandon has worked with in the past. Nonetheless, the firm's method is expected to be the same. Ms. Tandon will occupy an office near that of Chase's chairman, Thomas G. Labrecque, and she will lead several dozen top executives in seven-day-a-week, 16-hour-a-day cost-cutting marathons.    "We want to be as efficient a company as there is in this business," said Arjun Mathrani, the chief financial officer at Chase. He said the bank had chosen Tandon because of its bold, intensive approach. "We wanted to do this in a way that is highly concentrated so it doesn't extend over a long period of time," he added.   Chase is starting to organize its executives into teams, which will measure the costs of its existing businesses and then recommend improvements. All employees will be asked for efficiency ideas. By the end of this year, bank executives will select the ideas to be used, with all of the savings achieved by March 1997.   Mr. Mathrani declined to specify how many jobs would be eliminated or how much money would be saved, as Tandon's method is to push bank employees to think of the maximum possible cutbacks.   "I have no idea how this will play out, but there will be some head-count reduction, no doubt about it," he said.   Chase has been trying to cut its costs for more than a year, but the pressure increased last month when the activist investor Michael F. Price bought 6.1 percent of Chase's stock and called on it to make radical changes. Mr. Mathrani said, however, that Chase began speaking to Tandon in January.    Republic, by contrast, already has a reputation of being one of the leanest banks in the country. Nonetheless, it was driven to cut deeper because of new, more efficient, competitors.    "We recognized that we were not able to mach the low delivery costs of the Charles Schwabs and Fidelitys of the world," said Walter H. Weiner, chairman of Republic.   He said the bank, which has never had such a wave of layoffs, would offer severance pay that was much greater than the industry norm. For example, employees with more than 20 years at the bank will be paid for five years, in declining amounts, if they do not find other work.   The severance package and other costs of the campaign will cause Republic to take a $120 million pretax charge against earnings in the second quarter. The program is expected to eventually cut $75 million a year from pretax expenses.   At Republic, Tandon asked employees for suggestions on what processes could be streamlined or eliminated. Of the bank's 5,500 employees, 70 percent submitted ideas. The 21,000 suggestions were pared to 3,000 proposals for the bank's top management, and 2,000 were approved.   As a result of the process, the company will deliver management information on computer screens, rather than paper printouts. And it will cut the number of bankers who must approve certain loans from five to three.   All Republic employees had to describe their work functions in blocks of 5 percent of their time. As various functions were dropped, assignments were rearranged so that entire positions could be eliminated.   Republic rejected some of the suggestions, like raising the deductibles on insurance policies, as too risky. And it chose not to consider moving operations outside New York City.   Unlike Fleet, Republic decided to keep its corporate coffee service.  "We would be sending people into the neighborhood to get coffee," Mr. Weiner said. "And when they came back carrying coffee cups, they would spill it all over our carpets."   But the company will no longer pay anyone to water its plants.   "We think that it takes very little time for people to water their own plants," Mr. Weiner said.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF DANELLE MORTON; Dancing With I.R.S. Takes Time
abstract: IN the 1980's, my taxes took 10 minutes with the 1040EZ and I received my refund well before April 15. This was before real income and responsibilities -- like two children and college savings and retirement planning. Now my tax return is roughly the size of my college thesis and constructed from documentation just about as shoddy. I need every day until Aug. 15 to prove my tax-time thesis that the Government owes me money.  I take this so seriously that I couldn't possibly sign my return swearing it "true, correct and complete" by April 15. Or even by April 17, which is this year's deadline.

headline: TELEDYNE SHAREHOLDERS ADVISED TO REJECT WHX MOVE
abstract: Teledyne Inc., an aerospace, industrial and consumer products company based in Los Angeles, said yesterday that a shareholder advisory group had recommended that shareholders reject two nominees of the WHX Corporation to the Teledyne board. WHX, a steelmaker based in Wheeling, W. Va., is seeking to acquire Teledyne for $1.2 billion in cash and stock. In its bid, WHX is trying to win two seats on the Teledyne board. The adviser, Institutional Shareholder Services Inc., of Bethesda, Md., said Teledyne's shareholders should re-elect the company's seven incumbent directors at the annual meeting on April 26, Teledyne said.

headline: Dreamworks Link Sought by Michael
abstract: George Michael is negotiating a recording contract that would give the domestic distribution rights for the singer's music to Dreamworks S.K.G. and the foreign rights to Virgin Records. The arrangement would extricate the recording star from his contract with Sony Music, with which he has had a legal battle since 1989.    Executives at Sony and Dreamworks declined comment, but those with knowledge of the talks said a signing could be weeks, even months, away.

headline: Russia Revokes Visa Of U.S. Journalist
abstract: The Russian Government has revoked the visa of an American journalist in what may be the first such case since the collapse of the Soviet Union.    Steve LeVine, a stringer for Newsweek and The Washington Post, was stopped by immigration officials when he arrived at Vnukovo airport in Moscow on Monday evening from Tbilisi, Georgia, and was informed that his multiple-entry visa had been invalidated. He was not permitted to leave the airport, and spent the night in the airport's lounge before flying back to Tbilisi this morning.

headline: Deadly Virus Is Identified In the Outbreak in Zaire
abstract: Scientists have found preliminary evidence that the Ebola virus, one of the deadliest infectious agents known, is the cause of a mysterious disease that has broken out in Zaire, officials of the World Health Organization and the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last night.   The disease has killed at least 59 people in Zaire, and health officials fear that panic may be making the situation there worse. Perhaps as many as 300 patients, doctors, nurses and other health care workers have fled hospitals in the affected areas, said Dr. Ralph H. Henderson, an assistant director general of W.H.O., a United Nations agency in Geneva.

headline: World News Briefs; U.S. Asks Cuba To Return Financier
abstract: The Administration said today that it had asked Cuba to return Robert L. Vesco, the indicted financier who fled fraud charges in the United States two decades ago, but it insisted it would not provide Havana with anything in exchange.   Cuba informed the United States last Friday that it had arrested Mr. Vesco, 59, on charges of taking actions offensive to the interests of the Cuban people, and asked for information about his crimes here.

headline: Bonds Surge On New Sign Of Slowdown
abstract: A Government report yesterday showing the biggest drop in factory orders in more than three years sent bond prices surging and the yield on the long bond to its lowest level in nearly 15 months.   The Commerce Department's report on factory orders for April added to evidence that the economy was slowing and convinced some investors that the Fed's next move, when it does come, would be a rate cut, not an increase.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4 Yields on treasuries and certificates of deposit are neck-and-neck. So why is one deal so much better than the other? Minding Your Business, by Laura Pedersen. MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6  Funds that use the financial equivalent of steroids to bulk up fast. By Edward Wyatt. SPENDING IT /Page 8  At these auctions, you don't need a financial adviser to walk off with the winning bid. You need a good gardener -- and perhaps a station wagon. By Geraldine Fabrikant. VOICES /Page 13  The case for making affirmative action permanent: how about co-workers and clients who never let you forget your race? From the Desk Of, by Lawrence Otis Graham.

headline: Dollar Slumps Against the Mark Ahead of the Election in France
abstract: The dollar tumbled against the German mark yesterday as dealers sold French francs and other currencies for marks ahead of the French presidential election on Sunday.   Investors are wary about the outcome of the election because of concern that the next president would not be as committed to a strong franc as his predecessors, currency dealers said.

headline: Help Sought For World Loan Unit
abstract: Representatives of the world's poorest countries stepped into the growing congressional debate about foreign aid today by issuing a strong appeal to the United States and other donor countries to continue supporting the International Development Agency.   The appeal was made after a meeting of finance ministers from 24 developing countries, known as the Group of 24, which sets the third world's economic agenda just as the Group of Seven sets the industrial world's. The International Development Agency is the unit of the World Bank that tries to encourage development in poor nations by giving them very low-cost loans.

headline: International Briefs; Danish Stock Drops
abstract: Shares in ISS International Service System of Denmark dropped 10 percent yesterday after the company said that it would not be able to meet its earlier earnings forecast.

headline: Tide Changes: Mexico's Rebels Talk
abstract: A new round of peace talks to end the uprising in Chiapas finally got under way today, as rebel supporters gave up their encampment and Government negotiators took their places at a table set up on a concrete basketball court in this poor Indian town.    Although the issues of Indian rights and poverty remain essentially what they were during a round of unsuccessful talks in February 1994, sweeping changes in Mexico have shifted the advantages of the two sides. One effect has been to diminish the impact of the issues at the heart of the conflict.

headline: 3 Health Systems Study Venture
abstract: Three of the nation's largest Catholic health care systems agreed yesterday to evaluate a merger that would create a $4 billion hospital and long-term care organization.   The Catholic Health Corporation, the Franciscan Health System and the Sisters of Charity Health Care Systems said they would explore a consolidation, which would encompass 66 hospitals and numerous long-term facilities in 20 states. A final agreement is expected by the end of 1995.

headline: Regional Banking Giants on the Line
abstract: The decision that has long concerned smaller banks across the country -- whether to merge with a larger bank or remain independent -- is becoming a pressing issue for regional giants as well.    The willingness of the First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark, the nation's 25th-largest banking company, to merge into the 9th-ranked First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., is a sharp strategic departure for First Fidelity, whose recent practice has been to buy smaller banks. But if First Fidelity -- whose chairman, Anthony P. Terracciano, is highly regarded in the banking industry -- now thinks it is too small to compete, then many investors and analysts expect other banking companies will come to a similar conclusion.

headline: Earnings for Times Company Climbed 54% in First Quarter
abstract: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 54 percent in the first quarter, reflecting higher profits in the company's operating groups as well as higher equity from forest products operations.   The company said its net income totaled $27.4 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $17.7 million, or 17 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

headline: Hayes Repayment Plan
abstract: Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. said today that it had filed a reorganization plan that would allow it to leave Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection by November, paying creditors in full.   The maker of computer modems said it would pay all claims 40 days to 60 days after the plan is confirmed by Federal Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta. As part of the plan, Hayes, a closely held company based in Norcross, Ga., said it would obtain about $60 million in capital from investors and credit facilities arranged by the Robinson-Humphrey Company.

headline: Flat Spending By Consumers During March
abstract: Consumers spent about $2 billion less in March than economists had anticipated, the Commerce Department reported today, contributing to what has become a marked, although largely welcome, slowdown from the economy's superheated pace of late last year.   Retail sales edged up two-tenths of 1 percent for the month, a rise not only shy of forecasts but more pronounced because February sales were revised sharply downward to post the biggest decline in a year.

headline: Trump Walks a Tightrope In Plan to Sell Casino Stock
abstract: In recent years Donald J. Trump has announced his return from the financial troubles that denied him the enormous yacht, the Boeing 727 and the helicopter he so adored. But a close reading of the documents he released last week as part of his plan to sell stock in his least troubled gambling casino shows the financial tightrope he is walking.    The announced purpose of the plan was to raise more than $250 million to double the gambling space at the Trump Plaza casino in Atlantic City and to develop a riverboat casino in Gary, Ind., documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission state.

headline: Bond Rally Sends Rates Downward
abstract: Bonds rallied yesterday, sending interest rates to their lowest levels in nearly a week on speculation that the Fed would cut short-term interest rates soon.    The policy-making Federal Open Market Committee met without changing the Fed's monetary policy. After the meeting, the Fed's spokesman simply said, "There is no further announcement."

headline: Haiti Battles to Keep Vote on Schedule
abstract: With Haitians scheduled to vote late this month in their first election since democracy was restored here last fall, organizers are struggling to keep the balloting on track and on schedule.   As many as a million voter registration cards have been reported missing, voter registration deadlines have repeatedly had to be postponed, a final list of candidates has not yet been made public, and scores of disqualified candidates are complaining that they have not been told why they cannot run. Because of those and other delays and uncertainties, campaigning for the more than 2,200 elective offices has barely begun.

headline: How the Clinton Administration Reversed U.S. Policy on Cuban Refugees
abstract: It took just over a month for a small group of top Clinton Administration officials to overturn 30 years of American policy toward Cuba.   The process started when Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, went to the Oval Office one Friday afternoon in late March to deliver a warning. He told President Clinton of the rage building among the thousands of Cubans detained at the Guantanamo Bay naval base -- a warning that the general in charge of the region was starting to send up the Pentagon chain of command.

headline: Mafia's Foes Fear Rome Is Faltering
abstract: Three years into Italy's latest and most successful war against the Mafia, Palermo's anti-crime prosecutors have growing doubts whether the Italian state still has the will to pursue the war to its next, most sensitive stage.   "We feel alone, and we are beginning to wonder whether there is anybody backing us," said Roberto Scarpinato, a deputy prosecutor in Palermo.

headline: Rivalry and Graft Mire West African Nations
abstract: There has never been a war between Ghana and Burkina Faso, but anyone trying to get from the capital of one of these West African neighbors to the capital of the other could be excused for thinking otherwise.   Both countries have national airlines with their own regional routes, yet there are no flights between them. Large numbers of Burkinabe have long lived in Ghana, and yet the main road linking the two countries is so strewn with potholes that, according to a local joke, the only drivers seen traveling in straight lines on the highway are drunks.

headline: Worst May Be Over in Zaire's Ebola Outbreak
abstract: With only six new cases of Ebola infection reported in Zaire over the last week, the World Health Organization said today that the epidemic of the deadly viral disease in the African country was "coming under control."   "The acute phase of the epidemic is over and transmission now has been greatly reduced, if not completely halted," W.H.O. said in a news release issued from the headquarters of the United Nations agency in Geneva.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Registers 4.6% Earnings Gain
abstract: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that earnings rose 4.6 percent in the first quarter, fueled by improving results in the United States and strong results in Latin America.   The maker of consumer products said net income rose to $156.5 million, or $1.05 a share, from $149.6 million, or 98 cents a share, in the 1994 first quarter. The most recent results included an earnings dilution of 6 cents a share, which had been expected, from the company's January purchase of the Kolynos South American oral-care business.

headline: Pentagon Lists 27 Who Face Threat Of Death in Haiti
abstract: The Pentagon has sent a classified cable to the American Embassy in Haiti, warning that over two dozen political opponents of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide may have been selected for assassination, senior Defense Department officials said today.    American military officials compiled the list in the last several days from intelligence information and after analyzing supposed "hit lists" that have circulated in Haiti and in the Haitian-American press.

headline: Water Contract For Puerto Rico
abstract: The Air and Water Technologies Corporation said this week that one of its units had received a five-year, $500 million contract to manage the water and waste-water treatment system of Puerto Rico.   The company's Professional Services Group will manage the day-to-day operations of the system, while the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority will manage the financing of the system and other activities.

headline: North Korea To Get Plants From Rival
abstract: A multinational consortium led by the United States decided officially today to provide North Korea with two South Korean nuclear reactors and moved toward selecting South Korea's state-controlled electric utility as the prime contractor.   The Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization acted immediately after the United States and North Korea issued a joint statement that ended the latest mini-crisis over the Communist nation's nuclear weapons aspirations.

headline: U.S. Looks Away as Iran Arms Bosnia
abstract: The Clinton Administration has chosen to ignore weapons shipments from Iran to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government that in the last year have added considerably to Bosnia's military firepower, American officials said today.   They said the United States has ample evidence of the Iranian deliveries, which are in violation of the United Nations embargo that bans arms shipments to all combatants in the Bosnian civil war. But they said the Administration had not tried in any way to cut off the flow. The Administration said last fall that it would no longer take part in efforts to enforce the embargo on shipments to the Bosnians.

headline: CROP GROWERS STOCK FALLS ON ANALYST'S REPORT
abstract: Shares of the Crop Growers Corporation plunged yesterday after an analyst for Dain Bosworth Inc. downgraded the stock on lower-than-expected earnings. Shares of Crop Growers, an insurer based in Great Falls, Mont., fell $11.625, to $12.625, in Nasdaq trading. On Monday Crop Growers reported first-quarter net income of $5.2 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with a pro forma loss of $368,000, or 9 cents a share. The company's stock started trading publicly last June. The analyst downgraded the stock to "hold" from "buy" because he said the lower share price reflected the value of the company. A spokeswoman for the company said "management believes it's well positioned to continue its growth in the crop insurance business."

headline: YOUNKERS SAYS HOSTILE BID BY CARSON PIRIE HAS FAILED
abstract: Younkers Inc. said yesterday that it believed a hostile suitor, Carson Pirie Scott & Company, had lost its bid to put the company up for sale, though shareholder vote totals at the company's annual meeting will not be available until June 2. Carson, a retailer owned by P. A. Bergner & Company, refused to concede. The Milwaukee-based retailer has been pursuing Younkers since October. Carson has consistently been rebuffed by Younkers, which is based in Des Moines. In early March, it sweetened its bid to $19 a share, or $170 million.

headline: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN TO BUY SIX SHIPS FOR $166 MILLION
abstract: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. is buying six container ships from the American President Companies for about $166 million, the companies said yesterday. The companies also agreed that the ocean shipping subsidiary of Alexander & Baldwin, the Matson Navigation Company, would operate five of the vessels on westbound voyages from the United States to Hawaii and Guam and make the vessels' space available to American President for the return trips east. Alexander & Baldwin is based in Honolulu, while American President Lines is based in Oakland, Calif.

headline: Mismanagement and Waste Erode U.N.'s Best Intentions
abstract: While the United Nations was trying to keep peace in Somalia last year, $3.9 million vanished from its headquarters in Mogadishu. The cash, lying inside a cabinet with a faulty lock, was stolen in what investigators believe was an inside job. A steel safe had been shipped in to store the money, but minus its combination.   The incident epitomizes some uncomfortable truths about the United Nations as it prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary. It was in Somalia for the noble purposes of delivering food to starving people, which it did for a time, and restoring civic order, which it did not.

headline: Dollar Is Off vs. Mark and Yen As Japan Trade Deadline Nears
abstract: The dollar slipped against the yen and some other leading currencies yesterday as traders grew more skeptical that the United States and Japan would reach an accord on auto trade.   American and Japanese negotiators met again yesterday in Geneva in an effort to find some sort of agreement to open Japanese markets to American cars and car parts. Washington has threatened to impose 100 percent tariffs on $5.9 billion of Japanese luxury cars if no accord is reached by midnight tonight.

headline: Hilton Casinos To Be Spun Off; Shares Tumble
abstract: Shares in the Hilton Hotels Corporation tumbled more than 8 percent yesterday, after the company, dispelling prospects that it would be sold, said instead that it would spin off its casino operations to shareholders.   Hilton also said it had been in talks about the sale of all or parts of the company, and that the discussions might continue. Details of those discussions will be presented to the board for approval at a special meeting next month, the company said.

headline: Real Estate; A law firm's New York office is moving from lower Manhattan to the Met Life Building.
abstract: AFTER 15 months of negotiations, the law firm of Winston & Strawn has signed a lease for two floors totaling 86,000 square feet in the Met Life Building, formerly the Pan Am Building, at 200 Park Avenue at 45th Street.  The firm, which is based in Chicago, will be moving its office from 175 Water Street in lower Manhattan, where it occupies about the same amount of space. The new lease, which was negotiated for Winston & Strawn by Mitchell L. Steir of the Julien J. Studley real estate brokerage, is for 16 1/2 years.

headline: Business Travel; Buying ticket-free travel in just a few seconds. You can do it on the Delta and USAir shuttles.
abstract: TWO air carriers, Delta Air Lines and USAir, are making life easier this spring for passengers on their shuttles between New York, Washington and Boston with the introduction of ticket-free travel.  Delta plans to expand an experiment with an AT&T; Smart Card that it has been conducting on the shuttle since last October, and USAir has just started a new ticketless program that creates an individualized computer profile for participating passengers.

headline: Clinton Visit To Ukraine Is Welcome
abstract: When the White House proposed that President Clinton stop here for a full day on his way home from the Moscow summit meeting, Ukrainian officials were flattered. But when the White House proposed that he spend a night in the capital, Ukrainian officials were slightly alarmed.   Foreign Minister Gennady Udovenko fretted publicly that Kiev did not have enough suitable hotel rooms to accommodate the American President and his entourage.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Imposing a Ban On All U.S. Trade With Iran    President Clinton said last night that he would cut off all United States trade and investment with Iran, including purchases by American companies that account for more than 20 percent of that country's oil exports, in a further effort to isolate it as an "inspiration and paymaster to terrorists."

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5  There are ghosts galore in it. But the only thing frightening about the new Casper movie is what it is doing to investors. By Kurt Eichenwald. MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6  For mutual fund companies, the easy money has been made. And rising interest rates aren't helping. By Edward Wyatt. EARNING IT /Page 10  Employee-leasing lightens the boss's load and improves employee benefits. If only it really worked that way. By Mukul Pandya. VOICES /Page 14  A Chicago father spends five years on the mommy track and hasn't looked back. Well, only a little. From the Desk Of, by Michael S. Perricone.

headline: Champion Planning to Increase Newsprint Prices by 10 Percent
abstract: The Champion International Corporation said yesterday that it would raise newsprint prices 10 percent on Sept. 1, in a move that is being watched carefully by newspaper publishers.   The publishers say the move by Champion could test whether newsprint suppliers are able to impose a new round of price increases on newspapers' largest raw material.

headline: Is a Trans-Atlantic Pact Coming Down the Pike?
abstract: An idea that seems self-evident economically, but almost impossible politically, has recently caught the attention of politicians, trade experts and business executives in Europe and North America -- a trans-Atlantic free-trade agreement.   Yes, it has been considered before and put aside. Yes, it would take years to negotiate. Yes, it might have to exclude agricultural subsidies.

headline: A Bull Market With Strong Legs and 'a Long Way to Go'
abstract: WITH the stock market hitting new highs, we asked three Wall Street strategists -- Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman Sachs, Michael H. Sherman of Capital Investments International and Byron R. Wien of Morgan Stanley -- to offer insights. They were surprisingly unified on several things: Cyclical stocks are cheap. Utilities are not. And there is no reason that the major averages cannot keep rising.    Q.  Most of the stock market averages are hitting highs even as the dollar drops. The latest mutual fund numbers show cash reserves for domestic funds at the lowest level since Jimmy Carter was President. The dividend yield on the Standard & Poor's 500 is about 2.65 percent, almost as low as it was at the market peak in 1987. Technology stocks zoom ever higher, and most new software initial public offerings soar the first day of trading.

headline: MORRISON KNUDSEN TO SELL ITS WESTERN AIRCRAFT UNIT
abstract: The financially beleaguered Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Western Aircraft Inc. unit to two Wyoming investors as part of its plan to focus on its core engineering and construction business. Morrison Knudsen said it would receive several million dollars from the sale of the aviation maintenance company, but it did not disclose a specific amount. Morrison Knudsen, based in Boise, Idaho, said it planned to sell its nine million shares of Western Aircraft to Al Hilde, owner of Satellite Aero Inc., based in Jackson, Wyo., and Allen Hoyt, Aero's president.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: BellSouth Will Cut Up to 11,000 Jobs     Conceding that an earlier program of job cuts had not reduced costs enough, BellSouth said it would reduce its work force by another 9,000 to 11,000 employees by the middle of 1997 and warned employees that further cuts would be announced in the fall.

headline: GRANCARE TO PURCHASE EVERGREEN HEALTHCARE
abstract: Grancare Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire a rival nursing home operator, Evergreen Healthcare Inc., in a stock transaction valued at about $155 million. The companies said the acquisition would create one of the nation's largest publicly traded nursing home operators, with 133 centers in 15 states. Under the terms of the agreement, each common share of Evergreen will be exchanged for 0.775 share of Grancare, which is based in Culver City, Calif. Evergreen, based in Carmel, Ind., has about 12.6 million shares outstanding. Shares of Grancare fell 75 cents, to $15.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Evergreen declined $1.50, to $11.625.

headline: From the 'good war' comes good marketing opportunities -- 50 years later.
abstract: FIVE decades after the end of what the author Studs Terkel termed "the good war," the good selling opportunities are just beginning.   Marketers and the news media are celebrating the 50th anniversary of the conclusion of World War II with advertising and promotions imbued with patriotism, nostalgia and even some humor. Many programs start today, V-E Day, when the Allies proclaimed victory in Europe in 1945. Some start later this spring or during the summer, culminating with Aug. 15, V-J Day, the Allied victory over Japan that ended the war.

headline: Mexican Tourism To Unit of D'Arcy
abstract: The Mexican Secretaria de Turismo in Mexico City has named the Noble/D.M.B.& B. unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in Mexico City to handle its North American tourism account, which had been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York since 1983. The billings were estimated at $4 million for the rest of the year; for 1996, they are estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

headline: Financial Fear And Retirement
abstract: To the Editor:   "Another Day Older And Running Out Of Time" (March 26) accurately assesses today's retirement savings problem.

headline: Staples Spot Wins Top Radio Prize
abstract: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York took top honors last night, winning the $100,000 prize for the best radio commercial at the fourth annual Radio-Mercury Awards presentation sponsored by the Radio Creative Fund of New York.

headline: Caremark Surges on Report of Settlement
abstract: Caremark International Inc.'s agreement to plead guilty in a kickback inquiry, thus ending a criminal investigation that had hung over the company for nearly four years, drew an enthusiastic response yesterday from investors and many analysts.    Caremark announced on Thursday night that it had settled all criminal and civil liabilities it had faced for violations of Federal and state regulations. The investigation centered on whether Caremark had paid kickbacks to doctors to draw patients into Caremark's home health care business. Caremark agreed to pay $161 million to the Federal and state governments; the payment will cause Caremark to take an after-tax charge of $110 million for the second quarter.

headline: F.C.C. Planning Mobile Radio License Auction
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission announced a plan today for auctioning off a new batch of specialized mobile radio licenses.   The commission will auction 1,020 new licenses for a part of spectrum that has traditionally been used for radio dispatch services for companies like taxi and trucking services. A number of companies are planning to use specialized mobile radio, or S.M.R., to offer a variety of new mobile services.

headline: Credit Agricole Stake
abstract: The Belgian Government wants to sell as much as 41.4 percent of its stake in Credit Agricole S. A., a Belgian retail bank. Credit Agricole, which has branches in rural Belgium and assets of 139 billion Belgian francs ($4.9 billion), confirmed the sale. The sale is part of the Government's state-asset sale program. ASLK-CGER Holding, a financial holding company fully owned by the Belgian Government, will retain a 25.1 percent stake in Credit Agricole.

headline: There's No Such Thing as a Free Trade
abstract: IT was a nice consumer revolution while it lasted. On May 1, 1975, the New York Stock Exchange put an explosive charge under the fusty old brokerage business by ending its 183-year-old system of fixing commission rates. At the opening bell that morning 20 years ago, Wall Street began slashing stock-trade commissions and the discount brokerage business was born.   The investing proletariat scored big by dealing with no-frills pioneers like Muriel Siebert & Company, Quick & Reilly and Charles Schwab. Leslie Quick Jr. remembers that he took out a tiny newspaper ad in 1975 trumpeting his 45 percent discount over the old, fixed rates and that "the phones rang off the hook."

headline: Westin Is Sold And Gets Chief
abstract: A group of investors completed the purchase yesterday of the Westin Hotel Company and the new owners installed a new chairman and chief executive.   The buyers are affiliates of the Starwood Capital Group, Goldman, Sachs & Company, and the Nomura Asset Capital Corporation. They paid $537 million for the hotel company, based in Seattle, to the Aoki Corporation of Japan, a markdown from the $561 million the investors agreed to pay Aoki six months ago.

headline: Into the Woods in Asia; Myanmar? North Korea? No Sweat for Hong Kong Firm
abstract: Francis Pike liked what he saw in North Korea on a reconnaissance trip for Peregrine Investment Holdings Ltd., the Hong Kong investment bank, in the fall of 1993.    It was a place of pervasive tyranny and cultish obeisance to a "great leader." The Communist Government was an international pariah, accused by the United States and other Western countries of feverishly building nuclear weapons, shipping missiles to the Middle East, fomenting terrorism, kidnapping its critics abroad and crushing domestic dissent. And the country was overwhelmed by poverty.

headline: Seeking Joy (and Crowds) in Mudville Inc.
abstract: After an eight-month absence, major league baseball returns this week, hoping all is forgiven. But just in case it isn't, the 28 teams are offering mea culpas, cut-rate tickets, free yearbooks, snappy slogans, car giveaways and European vacations.   All this largesse -- a virtual crazy-quilt of promotion -- is intended to win back disgruntled fans and revive ticket sales that have been hammered by the 234-day players' strike, the longest in sports labor history.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A new survey finds that responsibility for brand management sits on some surprising shoulders.
abstract: THE ISSUE of whether powerful brand names continue to be engines of sales growth remains one of paramount concern to consumer marketers. A study now being released on the subject offers some surprising conclusions.   The survey, "Brands at the Crossroads," is jointly sponsored by Bozell Worldwide and the Fortune Marketing arm of Fortune magazine.

headline: With 46th Algerian Journalist Slain, It's a Furtive Vocation
abstract: Mourad Hemaizi was coming home from his anchor job on Algerian national television around midnight on Saturday when he was ambushed by killers on a road a few yards from his apartment here.   Three terrorists took Mr. Hemaizi to a deserted area, tied him to a pole and shot him three times as his driver watched, newspapers said.

headline: KERR-MCGEE EXPECTING $400 MILLION FROM ASSET SALES
abstract: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said yesterday that it expected to raise $400 million from the sale of its petroleum refining and marketing assets. The company, based in Oklahoma City, said last year that it would sell its refineries piecemeal after the failure of a two-year effort to sell the unit as a whole. It has lined up agreements to sell a number of the assets, but no terms have been announced. Kerr-McGee shares fell $1.125 yesterday, to $53.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Russian AIDS Law Requires Testing for Most Foreigners
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin has signed a new AIDS law that imposes mandatory testing on almost all foreigners living here.   The law, which was made public today, requires foreigners who plan to spend more than three months in Russia to provide documentation that they are not infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, when they apply for a visa. Diplomats will be exempt, but the law does not specify whether foreigners already living in Russia will have to be tested before renewing their visas. Russians who work in certain professions, as yet unspecified, will also undergo mandatory testing.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Esquire, Men's Health and Rolling Stone find rare common ground in a promotion for Haggar.
abstract: IMAGINE Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola and Royal Crown teaming up to plug colas among iced-tea drinkers. Or McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's joining forces to assert that hamburgers are better than pizza.   In almost as unlikely a coalition of competitors, three magazines that are typically bitter rivals for advertising pages and dollars -- Esquire, Men's Health and Rolling Stone -- are cooperating for the first time to produce a promotional program for the Haggar Clothing Company.

headline: Good News But No Good Explanation
abstract: AT 12:58 last Tuesday afternoon, an auspicious event occurred in the corporate life of Presstek Inc.: the printing press technology company surpassed a total market value of $10 million -- per employee, that is.   Now, this tiny New Hampshire company -- which is followed by no major Wall Street analysts, has little in the way of profits, and employs only 86 people -- is worth more than $800 million.

headline: Are Good Times Gone For the Funds Industry?
abstract: THIS cannot be a good sign for the mutual fund industry: Jeffrey N. Vinik, who calls the shots for the $44 billion Fidelity Magellan fund -- the biggest fund in the galaxy -- has been reduced to touting his favorite technology stocks at a shopping center shoe store.   Improbable as it may seem, that was the scene one evening last week as several hundred people were shoehorned into the Salvatore Ferragamo boutique at Trump Tower in Manhattan. The multitude came not to buy fine Italian leather goods, but to hear Mr. Vinik's outlook on the stock market and the economy.

headline: Market Timing
abstract: Today Policy makers of the I.M.F. and World Bank gather in Washington to begin their Spring meetings. Today, the I.M.F. will release its semiannual look at the global economy. Monday The Justice Department and Microsoft appear before the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to appeal a Federal judge's rejection of their antitrust settlement. Analysts expect Amoco to announce earnings of 89 cents a share, Exxon to come in at $1.06, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing at 88 cents, Texaco 85 cents and USX $1.07.   Tuesday Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven nations are meeting in Washington. They are expected to discuss how to shore up the weakening dollar, although many analysts doubt any action will be taken. Existing home sales for March. Forecast: up 2.9 percent, to 3.53 million. Consumer confidence index for April. Forecast: 99.1, down from 101 in March. The Major League Baseball season finally opens tonight, with the Dodgers playing the Marlins in Florida. Chevron is expected to report earnings of 65 cents a share and Monsanto $1.90 a share. Wednesday Durable goods order for March. Analysts say inventories of durable goods rose sharply during the month, indicating that consumer demand has cooled. Forecast: down 0.1 percent.   Analysts estimate that Baker Hughes should report earnings at 17 cents a share and DuPont at $1.20 a share. Thursday Dow Chemical earnings expected at $1.71 a share; Procter & Gamble at 94 cents a share. Friday First-quarter G.D.P. Forecast: up 2.9 percent.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * 2-Way Media Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., to Lois Colby, Los Angeles, a unit of Lois/USA, to introduce Launch, a bimonthly entertainment CD-ROM magazine. The billings were estimated at $10 million.

headline: Moving? Prices Are Rising, So Get a Move On
abstract: It may soon cost Americans a lot more to move to a new address.  For more than a decade, a glut of trucks in the moving industry has kept a lid on prices. But now, as the industry absorbs its largest acquisition ever and girds for further consolidations and regulatory changes, consumers face the prospect of higher prices and fewer movers to choose from.

headline: International Briefs; In Brief
abstract: * AXA S.A., France's second-largest insurer, said yesterday that it planned to begin a car insurance business in Germany, Europe's largest insurance market. AXA said the unit would be operated through its German subsidiary, AXA Direkt Versicherung. AXA owns 60 percent of the Equitable Companies. * Motorola Inc. signed a multimillion dollar contract yesterday with the Indian Government to create that nation's largest cellular phone system, in New Delhi. Financial details were not disclosed. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., will design and install equipment to build a system to support 100,000 cellular phone subscribers, the company said. * British Petroleum's chemical division plans to invest $:20 million ($32.2 million) to expand production of ethylene by about 25 percent at its site in Grangemouth, Scotland, company officials said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2000 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are priced at par to yield 7.26 percent.

headline: Almost Anything Goes in Birth Science in Italy
abstract: First there were the "granny moms," a series of women who had babies in their 50's, even in their 60's. Then there was the case in January of baby Elisabetta, who was supposedly conceived from an egg taken from a woman who had died two years before and carried to term by her father's sister.   With these and other tales of artificial fertilization making headlines, the next announcement was not as amazing as it might seem.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Madison Avenue hails baseball's return, but don't try to increase those fees just yet, sports fans.
abstract: ONE of the loudest sighs of relief at the end of the longest, most bitter strike in baseball history is emanating from Madison Avenue, which spends an estimated $1 billion annually on sponsoring everything from broadcasts of games to the signs that festoon stadiums.   Yet that enthusiasm is tempered by the realization the strike has seriously damaged Major League Baseball, from the 921 lost games to the records that won't be set because of back-to-back shortened seasons. Advertisers, teams and the sport itself face a daunting task in trying to restore baseball's luster.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japan and U.S. Admit Missteps Over Trade     Japanese and American officials concede that they deeply miscalculated the other country's resolve in their trade confrontation, and so far, neither side can find a way out.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ARTHUR J. GALLAGHER & CO., Itasca, Ill., which provides insurance brokerage and risk management services, acquired BHK&R Inc. Minn., a closely held insurance agency, for undisclosed terms. RENT-WAY INC., Erie, Pa., which operates a chain of rent-to-own stores, agreed to buy McKenzie Leasing Corp., a privately owned rental chain, in a stock transaction valued about $18 million.  RUSSEL METALS INC., sold its White Pass Petroleum distribution business to Harbor Enterprises Inc. Anchorage, a petroleum marketing company, for $37 million (Canadian), or about $27 million. SHAWMUT NATIONAL CORP., Hartford, , a bank holding company, completed acquisition of 33-branch Northeast Federal Corp., Farmington, Conn., for about $182.4 million in stock.

headline: War Decoding Helped U.S. To Shape U.N.
abstract: American officials read coded messages sent by the Allies in the final months of World War II, and this helped the United States dominate the United Nations charter conference that opened in San Francisco 50 years ago this Tuesday, a historian reports.   Some 635 pages of diplomatic messages were intercepted and decoded by the United States Army Signal Security Agency, and delivered to high-ranking American officials like Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. and Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson.

headline: Weak Economic Data Send Treasury Prices Soaring
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday as retail sales fell short of expectations and the Consumer Price Index showed only a slight rise, adding fresh evidence of an economic slowdown and subdued inflation.   The gains caused interest rates to drop back to week-ago levels as a general optimism among traders about the prospects that the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates added to gains in bond prices throughout the day.

headline: International Briefs; Pirelli Reports A Profit for 1994
abstract: Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it returned to profitability in 1994, for the first time since 1990, as both its tire and cable operations made money again. The company said it would not pay a dividend, because its parent company lost money. That is because the profits in 1994 from the tire and cable companies will not be passed on to the parent, which would make the payout, until this year. Pirelli said the results from the first few months of 1995 indicated that the profit would rise again this year. Consolidated net profit was 110 billion lire, or $65 million, in 1994, in contrast to a loss of 62 billion lire in 1993. Pirelli lost almost 229 billion lire from 1991 to 1993. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Credit Cards On Internet Given a Lift
abstract: Hoping to make it as easy to buy things over the Internet as it is to push a button, Mastercard International and Visa International said yesterday that they had agreed to a standard for electronic credit card transactions.    In effect, Mastercard has agreed to join -- with minor modifications -- a system that Visa was developing with the Microsoft Corporation. The system is intended to be open in that other card companies and software vendors will be invited to participate.

headline: Rebels Without a Cause Terrorize Uganda's Poor
abstract: About half of the 50,000-member Ugandan Army is based around this weather-beaten, potholed frontier town where soldiers constantly patrol the streets with assault rifles slung on their shoulders.   But outside in the sparsely populated countryside, many of the villages are so terrified of a roving rebel group that the peasants hide at night in the fields and in trees.

headline: Market Place; Investors await clinical word on a new drug from Teva of Israel.
abstract: FOR shareholders of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the leading drug maker in Israel, the next few weeks could be pivotal because of its new drug, Copaxone, which shows promise in fighting multiple sclerosis but is no cure.   Next month, at a neurological conference in Munich, Germany, clinical results on Copaxone -- perhaps the make-or-break results -- will be presented, showing if Teva is really a $60 stock, as its proponents argue, or worth considerably less than the $34 or so for which it is now selling.

headline: Dow Rises 10.72 as U.S. Vainly Tries to Prop Up the Dollar
abstract: As the Clinton Administration tried unsuccesfully to keep the dollar from falling to another record low against the yen, the stock and bond markets seemed to respond, if only slightly.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.72 points, to 4,168.41, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.14 points, to 501.85. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.84 point, to 818.05.

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK CONFIRMS DEAL WITH MORGAN
abstract: The Bank of New York Company confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to buy the securities custody business of J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the world's largest operations that holds stocks and bonds for customers. Bank of New York will take over $800 billion in client assets that J. P. Morgan now holds in custody accounts, lifting its total assets under custody to almost $3 trillion. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, although analysts estimated that the bank had agreed to pay about $300 million. Most of the 1,000 J. P. Morgan employees in the custody business will move to Bank of New York in the next six to nine months. Bank of New York's shares rose $2, to $39.25, and J. P. Morgan gained $1.625, to $69.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Market Place; Sometimes speed can be everything in making money.
abstract: SOMETIMES, it's not what you know that determines whether you make money on your investments. It's how fast you can get to the trading desk to place your sell order.   That's how it was last week when Michaels Stores, a chain of craft and home decorating stores based in Irving, Tex., disclosed that it was having a lot of trouble moving merchandise and would not come close to meeting its profit targets for the current quarter.

headline: London Lawyer Charged in B.C.C.I. Case
abstract: A partner in a prominent London law firm, Simmons & Simmons, was charged yesterday with suppressing evidence crucial to an investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney of the criminal conduct of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.   The indictment, handed up by a New York State grand jury in Manhattan, says that the law partner, David Sandy, in 1992 illegally concealed the business diary of the former chief executive of BCCI Holdings (Luxembourg) S.A., the holding company for the rogue bank. That executive, Zafar Iqbal, headed BCCI Holdings for 15 months before the international bank was forced to close by regulators in Britain, the United States and several other countries on July 5, 1991.

headline: Health for Youth On Council's Agenda
abstract: The Advertising Council, the agency industry's public service organization, said yesterday that it would place additional emphasis on campaigns that benefit "the health and well-being" of the nation's youth.   As part of the new initiative, called "Commitment 2000: Raising a Better Tomorrow," the council will introduce multiple, multiyear campaigns focusing on social issues like health care, education, family and community concerns. The number of campaigns created during the next five years will be increased to as many as 45 from 30.

headline: Bomb in Medellin, Colombian Drug City, Kills 30
abstract: In a deadly illustration of the multiple security threats facing the Colombian Government, at least 30 people were killed and more than 200 wounded when a powerful bomb exploded late Saturday night in the city of Medellin during a music festival attended by thousands of people.   Colombian police and military authorities said today that they had not been able to establish a motive for the attack, which occurred one block away from a police barracks, and that no group had claimed responsibility for it. But they said that leftist guerrilla groups and gangs of cocaine traffickers had engaged in such acts of terrorism in the past and that they were investigating both possibilities.

headline: International Briefs; In Brief
abstract: Portugal's Government yesterday approved the sale of the country's largest cigarette maker, Tabaqueira. The cabinet decided the state would first sell 80 percent to a single investor, either domestic or foreign, through a system of bids. The rest will be sold in shares to workers and small investors. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and Kvaerner A.S. of Oslo, Europe's largest shipbuilder, said yesterday that they would collaborate to design new composite materials for use in ships, oil platforms and other sea structures. Graham Group P.L.C. offered yesterday to buy Erith P.L.C., a British maker of building materials, for $:55.4 million, about $88 million, and Erith's board has recommended that shareholders accept.

headline: Economic Scene; In Mexico-style crises, the I.M.F. could be a bankruptcy court.
abstract: BETWEEN quarrels over Bosnia, leaders of the seven economic powers meeting at Halifax last weekend made some progress on coping with the next Mexico-style financial crisis. What they did not do was make the conceptual leap toward transforming the International Monetary Fund from a rich (and occasionally wise) uncle for the developing world into a global bankruptcy judge for nations in trouble.   What a pity.

headline: Here's a Course in Personal Finance 101, the Hard Way
abstract: NICOLE WALTERS, a 20-year-old junior at the University of Texas, carries two Visa cards, two Mastercards, two department store credit cards -- and two part-time jobs to dig herself out of debt.   "I was buying things here and there and all of a sudden, $4,000 later, those little things added up," Ms. Walters said. She recalls buying a $600 car stereo, some clothes and gas for her car, but nothing else major.

headline: In Honda Case, Tales of Dealers' Culture of Bribes
abstract: A helicopter tour of Hawaii, $25,000 shopping sprees in Hong Kong and a swimming pool for his California home.   Such were the bribes -- "gratuities," he calls them -- that a former marketing executive at the American Honda Motor Company received from dozens of Honda dealers, according to his testimony during the last several days in Federal court here.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Starting Over In Latin America; Partnership Signals Revival Of Interest in Risky Market
abstract: It was hardly the typical leading indicator. But when Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski got into his red Porsche recently and headed south for Miami, that was as good a sign as any that the smart money was heading south, too, all the way back to Latin America.   Mr. Kuczynski, a trim 56-year-old investment banker, has been shifting his base to Miami for more than two years. Driving down in the Porsche with some of the last of his things, he was making a final break with his life up north, leaving behind a 33-year marriage and homes in New York and Washington.

headline: BEHIND THE SCENES; The Revenue Streams That Flow From 'The Bridges Of Madison County'
abstract: Movie merchandising has existed at least two decades, but the last 10 years have seen an acceleration of this trend, perfected by Walt Disney Company, as movie marketers have become more sophisticated in building revenue sources. The domestic film industry generated more than $5.4 billion in ticket sales last year, while licensing income from merchandising tie-ins to films and animated characters surpassed $17 billion, according to Karen B. Raugust of The Licensing Letter. "The Bridges of madison County," by Robert James Waller, is a hugely successful book, with more than six million copies sold, and has been on the best-seller list for almost three years. Perhaps inevitably, the book and the film version have generated a not-so-small cottage industry of their own. TY AHMAN-TAYLOR COST: $14.95 PRINTED: 6 million in the U.S.  MARKETED BY: Warner Brooks 1 -- THE MOVIE BASED ON THE BOOK The movie has taken in more than $36.4 million, with an average of 3,420 per screen, which is more than either "Casper" or "Braveheart." Caryn James, in a review for The New York Times, said the film "benefits from several choices that preserve the book's essential appeal - its dreamy surface and pedestrian moral - while minimizing its syrupy qualities." Plans are under way for videotape release later in the year. COST: $8 a ticket in New York TO DATE: $36.4 million MARKETED BY: Warner Bros. Films 2 -- THE BOOK BASED ON THE MOVIE BASED ON THE BOOK This book features photographs taken by Ken Regan during the film's production and tells the film's story in pictures with snippets of large-type text. Like the movie, this book is broken down into four one-day segments. COST: $22.95 PRINTED: 80,000 MARKETED BY: Warner Books 3 -- THE BOOK BASED ON THE CAMERA IN THE MOVIE At several points in the film, Clint Eastwood, playing a photographer, snaps pictures of bridges and other scenery. Given that the on-screen cameras he used actually had film, and the film was actually developed, and was in focus, which is not the easiest task while directing and acting, a merchandising opportunity was set into motion. The book features photos as they were taken with snippets of text. It is mostly blank pages and is intended as a journal. COST: $11.95 PRINTED: 70,000 MARKETED BY: Warner Books 4 -- THE COMPACT DISK FROM THE MOVIE The disk features a song composed by Clint Eastwood in addition to several jazz standards that are heard on a transistor radio in the film. The Eastwood song, "Doe Eyes," is heard several times in the film. COST: $15.95 NUMBERED PURCHASED: More than 250,000 since May 20 MARKETED BY: Warner Bros. records 5 -- THE PERFUME LINKED TO THE MOVIE The perfume is but one of the several ancillary products linked to the film. Warner Bros. has licenced tote bags, polo shirts and other apparel, a cookbook and picture frames with the Bridges imprint While the film is not the size-large merchandising blitz that accompanied "Batman Forever," with its numerous commercial tie-ins, the initial book and film have also increased visitors to Madison County in Iowa. COST: Varies by Product MARKETED BY: Licence by Warner Bros.

headline: INTERCONTINENTAL BANK-NATIONSBANK LINK DISCUSSED
abstract: Intercontinental Bank said yesterday that it was in talks about being acquired by the Nationsbank Corporation, a big banking company based in Charlotte, N.C. The Miami-based Intercontinental Bank, which has about $1.17 billion in total assets and 24 branches in Florida, said terms currently being discussed would value its stock at $30 a share. Intercontinental Bank stock was up $2.625, at $27.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

headline: International Briefs; GEC Alsthom Cutbacks
abstract: GEC Alsthom, a joint venture of the General Electric Company of Britain and Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France, said its transport division would cut 984 jobs because an order for 27 trains had been cut by 10. The company did not disclose who had reduced the order. GEC-Alsthom Transport has a total work force of 8,700. The jobs will be removed from the payroll over three years, and there will be a policy of voluntary retirement, the company said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: German Central Bank Chief Urges U.S. to Act on Dollar     The dollar is not going to rise against the Japanese yen or German mark, according to Hans Tietmeyer, the head of the Bundesbank, until the currency markets see President Clinton and Congress taking steps to reverse the United States' declining savings rate and to reduce the budget deficit.

headline: Thorn EMI Posts Rise In Operating Earnings
abstract: Thorn EMI P.L.C said yesterday that its pretax profit before one-time charges rose 23.1 percent in the fiscal year that ended on March 31. Thorn, which has interests in music, consumer rentals and security systems, reported pretax profit of $:423.6 million, or $667 million, compared with $:344.2 million a year earlier. Thorn incurred one-time charges totaling $:126.9 million, including a loss of $:97.9 million for closing its electrical retailing chain Rumbelows.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan Inc.'s Dying Bit Players; Rising Yen Is Wreaking Havoc on Small Factories
abstract: Tomohiro Koseki is one of the unsung heroes of this nation's industrial miracle. A journeyman metal worker, Mr. Koseki can craft a turbine blade or a shaft to a precision of less than the thickness of a human hair. He has also written books celebrating the Japanese metal-working artisan. But Mr. Koseki, 62, said such craftsmen were now a dying breed.   In this city's Ota Ward, where he works, many of the small metal-working factories are falling victim to hard times and the soaring yen, leaving a feeling of helplessness, "like a carp on a cutting board." His own employer has only eight workers left, down from 20 a few years ago.

headline: CARSON PIRIE MAY RAISE BID FOR YOUNKERS
abstract: Carson Pirie Scott & Company said yesterday that it was willing to raise its bid for Younkers Inc. to $20 a share, or $179 million, if an agreement could be signed by July 1. Carson Pirie, based in Milwaukee, earlier offered $19 a share, or $170 million, for Younkers, a retailer based in Des Moines, which spurned the bid as inadequate. Shares in Younkers rose $1 yesterday, to $18.375, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A caption last Sunday with a photograph of three executives of the Walt Disney Company misstated the status of one of them, Richard H. Frank. He resigned last month, and is not part of management's "new team."

headline: CIBA-GEIGY AND MEDAREX TO DEVELOP NEW CANCER DRUG
abstract: The Swiss drug maker Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Medarex Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a partnership to develop and market Medarex's treatment for certain cancerous tumors. Medarex's product, MDX-210 Bispecific, is being tested as a potential treatment for breast, ovarian, prostate and other cancers. Under the agreement, Ciba-Geigy will spend $8 million to acquire common shares of Medarex, a biopharmaceutical company based in Annandale, N.J. In addition, Ciba-Geigy will provide as much as $31 million for research and development and pay all costs relating to clinical trials, regulatory approval and the introduction of MDX-210. Shares of Medarex rose 87.5 cents, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Clinton and Major Patch Up Quarrel on Northern Ireland
abstract: With British-American relations at their lowest point in years, President Clinton and Prime Minister John Major emerged from nearly three hours of meetings today and declared that the two countries had largely patched up their differences.   Seeking to put the best face on their recent quarrel over Northern Ireland, the two acknowledged that some disputes were inevitable.

headline: GENETICS INSTITUTE TO TEST PLATELET DRUG FURTHER
abstract: Genetics Institute Inc. said yesterday that it would move its platelet restorative factor into Phase 3 trials by the end of the year after earlier tests showed positive results. The company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said its Phase 2 results announced on Wednesday showed 30 percent of the patients getting Neumega Il-11 at a higher dosage did not require platelet transfusions. At a lower dosage, 18 percent did not require transfusions. The patients tested had a variety of cancers. The results were statistically significant. Analysts say the market for platelet restorative factors could be $500 million a year worldwide. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Genetics Institute closed up $3.125 at $37.125.

headline: Muslim Shrine In Kashmir Is Destroyed
abstract: An Indian Army siege of Muslim militants holed up in one of Kashmir's most revered Muslim shrines ended before dawn today with a fire that destroyed the shrine. The episode threatened to torpedo India's plans to try to address a five-year-old separatist insurgency in Kashmir with elections next month.    The destruction of the 15th-century mausoleum of Sheik Nooruddin Wali, considered Kashmir's patron saint, and an adjoining mosque followed a two-month standoff between several thousand Indian troops and 150 Muslim militants.

headline: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC. (PWJ,N)
abstract: Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 38 percent from the period a year earlier. Still, its profit exceeded Wall Street's expectations, mainly because of improved trading revenue.   Paine Webber, the nation's fourth-largest securities firm in terms of brokers, said net income fell to $34.3 million, or 27 cents a share, from $55.6 million, or 71 cents, in the 1994 quarter, when there were fewer shares outstanding.

headline: Indonesia Cleansing Its Press Of Writers Who 'Insult' Rulers
abstract: The Indonesian Government is purging the nation's newspapers and magazines of reporters who write critically about the Government, destroying the careers of some of the nation's best-known journalists and drawing protests from the United States and other foreign Governments.   Last month, the Government arrested several members of the Alliance of Independent Journalists, a group formed last August to challenge the censorship policies of President Suharto. At least two of the reporters are still in detention on charges of "insulting the Government," a crime that can carry a prison sentence of up to seven years.

headline: Cuba Tells U.S. It Will Not Extradite Fugitive Financier
abstract: The Cuban Government told American diplomats today that it does not plan to extradite Robert L. Vesco to the United States even though Cuba hinted after arresting him in Havana two weeks ago that it would hand him over, Administration officials said today.   State Department officials said they were disappointed by the decision, which came after the Clinton Administration told Cuban officials that it wanted Mr. Vesco returned so that he could be tried on embezzlement and narcotics charges.

headline: Hillary Clinton Meets Man Who Gave Her 2 L's
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has practiced law, raised a daughter and tried to change one-seventh of the American economy by reshaping health care. But in the last 24 hours she has ridden a bull elephant with Secret Service radio escort, and met the man responsible for making her a Hillary with two l's.   At an airstrip in Katmandu, Nepal -- just after an overnight tiger safari and just before her departure for this poverty-ridden pocket of South Asia -- Mrs. Clinton shook hands with Sir Edmund Hillary, the New Zealander who conquered Mount Everest with Tenzing Norgay in 1953. He was passing through town on his way to visit schools and a hospital in the Himalayan highlands financed by a foundation he heads.

headline: Purchase Plan by Arch Sparks Surge in Shares of USA Mobile
abstract: Shares of the USA Mobile Communications Corporation surged yesterday after Arch Communications Group Inc. announced it would buy the paging company for $253 million in cash and stock.    The deal would create the nation's second-largest publicly traded paging company, with 1.5 million customers in 26 states. Paging Network of Dallas is the nation's largest, with 4.5 million customers.

headline: Poppe Tyson to Add Jayme Organization
